ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about Kant, colonization, and the history of what Western thought.

How to independently do research, and write a paper over 100 pages long! Synthesising research and writing/editing on such a big scale was something I had never done before, and helped me gain confidence in my writing and analytic abilities.
Critical engagement w/ secondary literature, close interpretation and analysis

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was great, I got to complete a project that I had been working on for 3 years.

Strengths: having an advisor you have a good relationship with makes this a very rewarding and intellectually engaging process.
Weaknesses: it might have been nice to be held more accountable by having a weekly meeting time, the way other departments do, where students can talk about their topic and share their ideas with the community of philosophy majors, helping each other improve their theses by doing peer reviews or giving feedback to presentations.

I probably would vouch for the 2 term thesis over the 1 term option; I was quite time-constrained w/ the 1-term option and felt like I could have undertaken a more ambitious project had I had the extra semester.

My independent project was one of the highlights of my Yale career: I learned so much, both relating to my subject and to academia as a whole.

That said, the philosophy department can (and should!) do more to cultivate a collaborative environment. Students should be encouraged to share their projects with other students and professors casually, if not in a formal thesis working group like in the religious studies department. Philosophy could also inaugurate thesis awards to motivate hard work and bring together its students under shared goals and landmarks. It would be great for the thesis to not be a solitary effort between student and adviser, but rather something in engagement with the department as a whole.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you have something that you're very curious about, a good question, then absolutely. If not, just take a seminar, that's often where good questions first emerge.

Yes! doing a thesis is so rewarding and it's so amazing to walk away from Yale with a material representation of a big part of the things that you have learnt and thought about during your years here. (It's also not as stressful as people make it seem.)

I highly recommend taking the 1 or 2-term senior thesis option; I know it's not a requirement for the major but I found it an incredibly fulfilling and exciting experience to take so much ownership over my own academic project.
